close_symbols: global object table(s) used by the ObjectId/convert routines (e.g. OS_object_table)
string.h functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn)
explanation:
For MISRA C Rule checking of out-of-bounds accesses by string.h functions, you must inspect not only the target function but all functions it calls and the data they operate on:

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: Direct callee of OS_CountSemGive; must be inspected for any use of string.h functions or buffer accesses involving sem_id or token.
- OS_CountSemGive_Impl: Called when OS_ObjectIdGetById succeeds; must be inspected for string/memory operations and how it uses the token.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit / OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex / OS_ObjectIdConvertToken / OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: These are the internal callees of OS_ObjectIdGetById (per the static call graph). Any of them could perform memory copies, string operations, or index/length calculations that lead to out-of-bounds accesses; they must be reviewed.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Callee of OS_CountSemGive_Impl that likely dereferences token fields or indexes arrays — inspect for unsafe accesses.

Type/constant symbols (needed to understand sizes, encodings and control flow):
- OS_object_token_t: The structure layout and field types/sizes/pointer semantics are needed to check whether any string/memory operations on token fields are safe.
- osal_id_t: Type and encoding of sem_id determine valid ranges and how it is converted/used.
- LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, OS_SUCCESS, int32: Constants and the return type used in control flow; required to determine which code paths execute and when called buffers/tokens are initialized or used.

Global state referenced by the ObjectId/conversion routines:
- global object table(s) used by the ObjectId/convert routines (e.g. OS_object_table): Many object-id helpers index into global arrays; the layout and element sizes are needed to check array bounds and any mem/str operations on stored names/fields.

Library functions to look for:
- string.h functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn): The rule targets these functions specifically — search for usages of these functions (or wrappers) in the above symbols to determine any potential out-of-bounds accesses.

Reviewing the listed functions, types, globals and any uses of the standard string/memory routines will allow a complete determination whether OS_CountSemGive (via its callees) can result in accesses beyond buffer/object bounds.
